data.title: A Look At Data#3 (ASX:DTL) Valuation After Higher Half Year Earnings And Dividend Announcement
data.description:
Data#3 (ASX:DTL) has attracted fresh attention after releasing half year results to December 31, 2025, alongside declaring a fully franked interim dividend of A$0.135 per share with payment scheduled for March 31, 2026.

See our latest analysis for Data#3.

Despite the earnings release and higher interim dividend, recent momentum has been weak. The 7 day share price return is 23.17% and the 30 day share price return is 25.42%, while the 1 year total shareholder return of 6.53% contrasts with a 5 year total shareholder return of 69.93%. This suggests longer term holders have experienced stronger results than those who bought more recently.

If this update on Data#3 has you reassessing your tech exposure, it could be a good time to look at 33 AI infrastructure stocks picked out by the Simply Wall St screener.

So with earnings and dividends moving, but the share price showing weaker recent returns, is Data#3 quietly trading at an attractive entry point, or is the market already paying up for any future growth?

Advertisement

Most Popular Narrative: 71.9% Undervalued

According to the most followed narrative on Data#3, a fair value of A$25.40 sits well above the last close of A$7.13, which creates a wide gap between narrative pricing and where the market currently trades.

Data#3's reporting exemplifies ENRON-style disclosure engineering through: 1. Dual metric hierarchies: Promoting non-IFRS gross sales while suppressing GAAP revenue 2. Segment reclassification: Shifting struggling product lines between business units 3. Temporal cash management: Accelerating payables/deerring receivables to window-dress liquidity Investors should demand: * Full inventory aging schedule * Vendor rebate waterfall analysis * State-level P&L disclosures * Cash conversion cycle reconciliation The cumulative effect creates a 230-470bp overstatement of operational health, primarily through inventory valuation, rebate accounting, and geographic risk aggregation. This pattern suggests management anticipates worsening H2 conditions, making current obfuscation practices a leading indicator of future earnings risks.

Read the complete narrative.

Want to understand why such aggressive disclosure concerns still sit alongside a much higher fair value? The narrative leans heavily on strong cash generation, revenue expansion and premium profitability assumptions to justify that A$25.40 figure without treating the current share price as an anchor.

However, such a large gap to fair value could unwind quickly if the disclosure concerns around inventory, cash flow, and vendor rebates are validated by future filings.

That A$25.40 fair value is not the only story in town. Our DCF model, using projected future cash flows, points to a fair value of A$3.67. data.title: GlobalFoundries Renesas Deal Reshapes Auto Chip Capacity And Revenue Visibility
data.description:
• GlobalFoundries and Renesas Electronics have agreed a multi billion dollar partnership to support a more resilient semiconductor supply chain.
  • The collaboration focuses on expanding US based chip production for automotive and industrial customers.
  • The agreement targets long term capacity and supply arrangements at GlobalFoundries facilities.

GlobalFoundries, listed as NasdaqGS:GFS, is drawing fresh attention as investors weigh this large scale manufacturing agreement against recent share performance. The stock trades at $48.86, with returns of 5.0% over the past week, 10.5% over the past month, and 32.5% year to date. Over the past year, the share price return is 20.3%, while the 3 year figure reflects a 25.0% decline.

For investors tracking US chip manufacturing and supply chain themes, this Renesas partnership adds a new piece of information to the GlobalFoundries story. It ties the company more closely to automotive and industrial chip demand and outlines a longer term production relationship that may influence how you think about capacity, revenue visibility, and capital intensity over time.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for GlobalFoundries by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on GlobalFoundries.

üì∞ Beyond the headline: 0 risks and 3 things going right for GlobalFoundries that every investor should see.

This Renesas agreement gives GlobalFoundries another anchor customer for its specialty platforms in areas like automotive microcontrollers, power management, and industrial control. For you as an investor, the key point is the potential for longer term, contract based wafer demand tied to US based fabs, rather than one off, short cycle orders. That kind of arrangement can support more predictable factory loading and may help justify large capital projects in places such as New York and Vermont. At the same time, locking in capacity for one partner can limit flexibility if end demand shifts, so the quality of the commercial terms and any take or pay elements matter. Renesas gains access to a geographically diversified production base. GlobalFoundries deepens its role as a non leading edge foundry alongside players like TSMC and UMC in auto and industrial markets where supply security is often just as important as cutting edge nodes.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The GlobalFoundries Narrative

  • The partnership lines up with the narrative focus on automotive and communications chips, and on long term agreements that can support scale benefits in US and European fabs.
  • It could test the narrative around capital efficiency if meeting Renesas demand requires higher upfront spending or lowers pricing power compared with other customers.
  • The specific emphasis on supply chain resiliency and on shoring for a Japanese chipmaker is not fully captured in the existing storyline and may add another angle to GlobalFoundries role in government supported manufacturing.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for GlobalFoundries to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Higher capital spending to support dedicated capacity for Renesas could pressure free cash flow if wafer volumes or pricing do not match expectations.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Concentrating more output on auto and industrial customers may increase exposure to sector specific cycles and competition from foundries such as TSMC and Samsung expanding their own regional capacity.
  • üéÅ A multi billion dollar, long term partnership can support better capacity utilization, revenue visibility, and closer product co development with a key customer.
  • üéÅ The focus on US, European, and Asian facilities supports the reward theme of regionally diversified manufacturing that may appeal to customers prioritizing supply security and government incentives.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, keep an eye on any extra disclosures around the duration, minimum volume, and pricing framework of the Renesas agreement, because those details will shape how you think about GlobalFoundries earnings quality. Updates on capacity plans at its US fabs, and whether Renesas production later extends to Germany, Singapore, and China, will also signal how embedded this relationship becomes. Comparing GlobalFoundries order trends and long term deals with peers like TSMC and UMC can help you judge whether the company is keeping pace in auto and industrial markets. Finally, management commentary on capital intensity and returns on new projects will be important to track as more of the portfolio is tied to supply chain resilience programs.

To ensure you're always in the loop on how the latest news impacts the investment narrative for GlobalFoundries, head to the community page for GlobalFoundries to never miss an update on the top community narratives.

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a company could be worth by projecting its future cash flows and then discounting them back to today‚Äôs value in $.

For Infinity Natural Resources, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The latest twelve month free cash flow (FCF) is a loss of $283.8 million, so the company is currently consuming cash rather than generating it. What counts as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/S depends on how quickly revenue is expected to grow and how risky that revenue stream is. Higher expected growth or lower perceived risk can justify a higher multiple, while slower growth or higher risk usually points to a lower one.

data.title: DigitalBridge Pauses Earnings Call As SoftBank Deal And Profit Shift Loom
data.description:
• DigitalBridge Group (NYSE:DBRG) has announced it will not hold its usual earnings conference call.
  • The company will also pause detailed financial guidance while it pursues a proposed transaction with SoftBank Group Corp.
  • This reflects the importance of ongoing discussions with SoftBank, a major investor in digital infrastructure.

For you as an investor, the absence of an earnings call means fewer near term management updates at a time when interest around DigitalBridge Group is elevated. The shares most recently closed at $15.35, with a 1 year return of 37.1% and a 3 year return of 24.0%, while the 5 year return sits at a 34.2% decline. That mix of performance highlights why potential changes around ownership or direction are likely to draw close attention.

With no detailed guidance on offer, the focus shifts to the proposed SoftBank transaction and what it could mean for DigitalBridge Group's role in digital infrastructure. Until there is more clarity, you may want to pay close attention to official company announcements, given how material this process could be for NYSE:DBRG shareholders and creditors.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for DigitalBridge Group by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on DigitalBridge Group.

We've flagged 2 risks for DigitalBridge Group. See which could impact your investment.

DigitalBridge pausing its usual earnings call and guidance puts a spotlight on the proposed SoftBank deal rather than the quarter itself. That is important context, because the latest numbers are mixed. Q4 2025 revenue of US$47.9 million compares with US$66.17 million a year earlier and full year revenue of US$93.96 million compares with US$607.03 million, yet the company reported Q4 net income of US$65.06 million versus a net loss of US$5.05 million and full year net income of US$141.87 million versus US$70.52 million. That combination of lower revenue with higher profit points to one off items, portfolio reshaping, or business mix changes that are harder for you to assess without a live Q&A. With SoftBank in the picture, the key question becomes how DigitalBridge‚Äôs fee based, digital-infrastructure-focused model might sit inside a larger group that is already active around AI and data centers. Until management gives more detail, you are relying on filings and the investor presentation to judge how repeatable recent earnings are and how much of the future story depends on SoftBank ownership.

How This Fits Into The DigitalBridge Group Narrative

  • The focus on SoftBank lines up with the narrative that positions DigitalBridge at the center of AI driven data center demand, as SoftBank has been linked to AI and digital infrastructure themes globally.
  • The lack of guidance and limited color on the large swing in revenue and earnings could challenge the narrative‚Äôs emphasis on recurring revenue and earnings predictability.
  • The SoftBank proposal itself is not explicitly embedded in the existing narrative, so any future change in ownership, capital support, or growth priorities may alter how those earlier AI and power related catalysts play out.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è A potential change of control raises execution risk around culture, incentives, and capital allocation, especially with strong competitors like Blackstone, Brookfield, and KKR also active in digital infrastructure.
  • üéÅ The proposed SoftBank transaction could provide deeper pockets and a broader ecosystem for scaling data center and AI related projects, which may support DigitalBridge‚Äôs platform ambitions.
  • üéÅ Recent profitability, including Q4 net income of US$65.06 million, gives you more evidence of earning power than a period that only contained losses, even if some items may be one time in nature.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, you will want to track three things closely. First, any additional detail on the SoftBank terms, including timing, conditions, and what DigitalBridge‚Äôs operating structure would look like after closing. Second, disclosures in the 2025 Form 10 K and investor materials that break down what drove the sharp revenue change and profit improvement, and whether management labels any items as non recurring. Third, any commentary on how DigitalBridge plans to compete for AI related data center and power projects against other large asset managers if the SoftBank transaction is delayed or does not proceed. That context will help you judge whether today‚Äôs earnings profile looks sustainable or is in transition.

  • What stands out is how this valuation discussion balances against the growth profile:
    • On one side, the lower P/E than industry and peers supports the idea that the stock is priced more cheaply relative to its earnings than many software names, even after a 21.7% lift in earnings over the past year.
    • On the other, revenue and earnings are both forecast to grow more slowly than the broader Singapore market, at 1.6% and 2.2% per year respectively versus 4.4% and 7.4%. Any case that the shares deserve a higher multiple rests on investors being comfortable with that slower growth profile.

data.title: Eastman Chemical Results Highlight Cash Strength Recycling Progress And Dividend Questions
data.description:
• Eastman Chemical (NYSE:EMN) released its full year 2025 results, emphasizing strong cash generation.
  • The company reported that it exceeded its cost reduction targets for the year.
  • Management also highlighted progress at the Kingsport methanolysis plant, where recycling efforts advanced further.

Eastman Chemical, a global specialty materials producer, continues to focus on cash generation and cost discipline while operating in a mixed economic backdrop. For investors, the latest update on the Kingsport methanolysis plant matters because it ties Eastman's core plastics and chemicals businesses to circular recycling efforts that many brands and regulators are watching closely.

Looking ahead, the combination of cash generation, ongoing cost control, and visible progress on recycling may keep NYSE:EMN on the radar for investors who care about both income and sustainability. The company‚Äôs history of dividend payments, together with its recycling initiatives, provides a couple of clear themes to track in future annual updates.

For dividend-focused investors, Eastman Chemical‚Äôs full year update links directly to how dependable its cash returns might be. The company highlighted strong cash generation and again affirmed a quarterly dividend of $0.84 per share, which continues a multi year pattern of regular payments. At the same time, Simply Wall St‚Äôs risk checks point out that the dividend is not well covered by free cash flow and that debt is not well covered by operating cash flow. The recent issue of US$600m in 4.50% senior unsecured notes due 2031 adds another fixed claim on future cash. Together, those details suggest you may want to look closely at payout ratios, interest costs, and how much cash is left for reinvestment after dividends and debt service.

  • The additional debt and flagged concerns about cash flow coverage could challenge the idea that cost savings alone will keep returns to shareholders comfortable if end market demand stays weak.
  • The fixed income issuance and detailed recycling ramp at Kingsport add extra color on capital structure and sustainability execution that is not fully captured in the high level narrative.

data.title: Vistra Bets On Gas And Nuclear To Power Data Center Demand
data.description:
• Vistra (NYSE:VST) has committed around $4 billion to acquire natural gas and nuclear power plants, targeting rising electricity needs from data centers.
  • The company reports significant growth in EBITDA and dividends alongside this expansion in generation assets.
  • These moves mark a shift in Vistra's business mix toward serving large, power intensive customers such as data centers.

Vistra, a major US power producer and retailer, is leaning into the surge in electricity demand tied to data center build outs. By adding natural gas and nuclear capacity, NYSE:VST is increasing its exposure to dispatchable power that can serve round the clock loads. For investors, the mix of large asset purchases and higher dividends puts both capital allocation and balance sheet decisions in focus.

The company is positioning itself to be a key supplier to data centers that require reliable, large scale power. The combination of new generation assets and a growing dividend stream gives investors several angles to watch, from cash flow stability to how effectively Vistra integrates and operates its expanded fleet.

For Vistra, committing around US$4b to natural gas and nuclear assets is a clear push toward long term, contract backed cash flows from power intensive customers such as data centers. These plants can run consistently, which lines up with the 24/7 needs of hyperscalers and large corporates. The reported 13.9% growth in adjusted EBITDA over the first nine months of 2025 sits alongside a dividend profile that includes a common dividend with a five year compound annual growth rate of 10.7% and a preferred Series A payout of US$80.00 per share on an annualized basis. That combination suggests management is comfortable returning more cash to shareholders while still writing large checks for acquisitions. For you as an investor, the key question is whether the earnings base from these acquired assets and power contracts can comfortably service higher interest costs, ongoing capital spending, and both common and preferred dividends over time.

  • The recent step up in common and preferred dividends is not fully reflected in the narrative and adds another layer of capital allocation that could influence how much cash is left for renewables and storage projects.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Profit margins of 5.6% compared to 11.4% last year indicate pressure on profitability, which may matter if power prices or plant availability move against Vistra.
